Sure, here are the drawbacks mentioned for each mode:

1. Empirical Mode (EM)
* Hard for simple empirical models to meet the accuracy requirements of water quality parameters concentration estimation
* Poor generalities due to regional and temporal constraints
* Requires a lot of field water quality sampling data as the basis to assure relatively higher accuracy
2. Analytical Mode (AM)
* Composition of water body and radiation transmission procedure is rather complex because many factors need to be measured for the model to be established
* Spectral resolution of most satellite sensors and those measured near the ground are inconsistent, leading to difficulties in model research
* Quantitative remote sensing inversion based on the analytical mode is difficult to achieve and is limited in practical applications
3. Semi-Empirical Mode (SEM)
* None mentioned in the paragraph
4. Artificial Intelligence (AI) Mode
* Establishing a neural network for water quality retrieval requires a large number of samples to be trained with extensive experiences, otherwise there may be under-learning or over-learning situations, which greatly limit the neural network model inversion accuracy
* Increase in the number of training samples will make SVM algorithms difficult to implement and run slowly.
